italian_dressing.name: Italian Dressing
italian_dressing.description: Italian-style salad dressing, typically made with oil, vinegar, herbs, and spices. Provides healthy fats from oil but often high in sodium. Choose oil-based varieties over creamy versions for better heart health.
healthBenefits: Provides vitamin E from oil, supporting antioxidant protection
Vitamin K supports blood clotting and bone metabolism
Oil-based dressings help absorb fat-soluble vitamins from salad greens
Polyunsaturated fats from vegetable oil support cell membrane health
Minimal calories when used in moderation for salad flavoring

nutritionContext.portionGuidance: Use 1-2 tbsp to dress salads. High sodium content means portion control is important, especially for those managing blood pressure. Consider making homemade versions with less sodium.
nutritionContext.preparationTips: Make your own Italian dressing with olive oil, vinegar, garlic, oregano, basil, and minimal salt for better nutrition. Store-bought versions often contain additives and excess sodium.
nutritionContext.pairingRecommendations: Use on mixed green salads, pasta salads, or as a marinade for chicken and vegetables. Pair with leafy greens rich in vitamins A, C, and K to enhance fat-soluble vitamin absorption.
nutritionContext.timingConsiderations: Use at lunch or dinner to enhance vegetable consumption. The fat content helps slow digestion and increases satiety from salads.

balsamic_vinegar.name: Balsamic Vinegar
balsamic_vinegar.description: Traditional Italian vinegar made from grape must, aged in wooden barrels. Rich, sweet-tart flavor with antioxidants from grapes. Zero fat, low calorie, and adds sophisticated flavor to salads and dishes.
healthBenefits: Contains polyphenolic antioxidants from grapes that reduce oxidative stress
Acetic acid may help regulate blood sugar spikes after meals
Very low in calories, making it ideal for weight management
May help improve insulin sensitivity when consumed with high-carb meals
Contains trace amounts of potassium supporting heart health
Minimal sodium makes it heart-friendly for those managing blood pressure

nutritionContext.portionGuidance: Use 1-2 tbsp for salad dressing or drizzling. Traditional balsamic vinegar is more concentrated in flavor, so less is needed. Avoid 'balsamic glaze' products with added sugars.
nutritionContext.preparationTips: Look for 'Aceto Balsamico Tradizionale' for authentic aged balsamic with superior antioxidants. Mix with olive oil (3:1 ratio) for a simple, healthy salad dressing.
nutritionContext.pairingRecommendations: Drizzle over fresh tomatoes and mozzarella, roasted vegetables, strawberries, or mixed greens. Pairs excellently with extra virgin olive oil for a classic Italian dressing.
nutritionContext.timingConsiderations: Use with meals to potentially reduce post-meal blood sugar spikes. The acetic acid may slow carbohydrate digestion, making it beneficial with pasta or bread.

vinegar_distilled.name: Distilled White Vinegar
vinegar_distilled.description: Clear, distilled vinegar made from grain alcohol. Sharp, acidic flavor with virtually no calories or nutrients. Excellent for pickling, cleaning, and adding acidity to dishes.
healthBenefits: Virtually zero calories, perfect for weight management
Acetic acid may help improve insulin sensitivity and blood sugar control
No sodium, making it ideal for low-sodium diets
May help increase satiety when added to meals
Contains acetic acid which may support healthy digestion
Can be used to reduce need for salt in recipes, supporting heart health

nutritionContext.portionGuidance: Use 1-2 tbsp as needed for pickling, salad dressings, or adding acidity to dishes. Generally safe in larger quantities due to zero calories and sodium.
nutritionContext.preparationTips: Dilute with water for drinking (some use for digestive support). Mix with herbs and oil for homemade salad dressings. Use in marinades to tenderize meat.
nutritionContext.pairingRecommendations: Use in coleslaw, pickled vegetables, or homemade condiments. Mix with olive oil, mustard, and herbs for a simple vinaigrette. Add to bean dishes to enhance nutrient absorption.
nutritionContext.timingConsiderations: Some consume diluted vinegar before high-carb meals to potentially reduce blood sugar spikes. The acetic acid may slow gastric emptying, increasing satiety.

hot_sauce.name: Hot Sauce
hot_sauce.description: Spicy condiment made from chili peppers, vinegar, and salt. Contains capsaicin with potential metabolism-boosting properties. Very low in calories but can be high in sodium.
healthBenefits: Capsaicin may boost metabolism and increase calorie burning
Contains vitamin A from chili peppers, supporting immune function and vision
May help reduce appetite and increase satiety
Capsaicin has anti-inflammatory and pain-relieving properties
Virtually zero calories makes it ideal for adding flavor while managing weight
May support cardiovascular health by improving circulation

nutritionContext.portionGuidance: Use 1 tsp (or to taste) to add heat and flavor to dishes. High sodium content means portion control is important for those managing blood pressure. Start with small amounts and increase gradually.
nutritionContext.preparationTips: Choose hot sauces with simple ingredients (peppers, vinegar, salt). Avoid varieties with added sugars or excessive sodium. Make your own with fresh chilies, vinegar, and garlic.
nutritionContext.pairingRecommendations: Add to eggs, tacos, soups, stir-fries, or grilled meats. Use to spice up vegetables, making them more appealing. Mix with Greek yogurt or avocado for creamy, spicy dips.
nutritionContext.timingConsiderations: The capsaicin may temporarily boost metabolism. Some find it stimulating, so avoid before bed if sensitive. Use at breakfast or lunch to potentially increase calorie burning throughout the day.

bbq_sauce.name: BBQ Sauce
bbq_sauce.description: Sweet and tangy barbecue sauce made from tomatoes, vinegar, sweeteners, and spices. Typically high in added sugars and sodium. Provides some antioxidants from tomatoes but should be used sparingly.
healthBenefits: Contains lycopene from tomatoes, a powerful antioxidant that may reduce cancer risk
Provides small amounts of potassium for heart health
Can make grilled meats and vegetables more palatable, encouraging healthier eating
Some varieties contain spices with anti-inflammatory properties
Minimal fat content compared to creamy condiments

nutritionContext.portionGuidance: Limit to 1-2 tbsp per serving due to high sugar and sodium content. Look for 'reduced sugar' or 'no sugar added' varieties to minimize added sugars. Use as a finishing sauce rather than marinade to reduce intake.
nutritionContext.preparationTips: Make homemade BBQ sauce with tomato paste, apple cider vinegar, spices, and a small amount of natural sweetener (like dates or honey) to control sugar and sodium. Store-bought versions often contain high fructose corn syrup.
nutritionContext.pairingRecommendations: Use sparingly on grilled chicken, pork, or plant-based proteins. Mix with Greek yogurt for a creamy, protein-rich dip. Pair with fiber-rich foods to slow sugar absorption.
nutritionContext.timingConsiderations: Best used occasionally as a flavoring agent rather than a daily condiment. If used, pair with protein and fiber to minimize blood sugar spikes. Avoid late at night due to sugar content.

barbecue_sauce.name: Barbecue Sauce (Generic)
barbecue_sauce.description: Generic barbecue sauce with sweet, smoky, and tangy flavor profile. Made from tomatoes, sweeteners, vinegar, and spices. High in added sugars and sodium. Nutritionally similar to standard BBQ sauce.
healthBenefits: Contains lycopene from tomatoes, supporting prostate and cardiovascular health
Provides trace amounts of potassium for blood pressure regulation
Can enhance flavor of grilled vegetables and lean proteins without added fat
Contains small amounts of vitamin A from tomatoes for immune support
Very low in fat compared to cream-based sauces

nutritionContext.portionGuidance: Use 1 tbsp sparingly as a condiment. High sugar and sodium content make it unsuitable for frequent use, especially for those managing diabetes or hypertension. Consider 'sugar-free' versions sweetened with stevia or monk fruit.
nutritionContext.preparationTips: Make homemade barbecue sauce using tomato sauce, apple cider vinegar, smoked paprika, garlic powder, onion powder, and a touch of molasses or date paste for natural sweetness with more nutrients and less sodium.
nutritionContext.pairingRecommendations: Use on grilled chicken breast, pulled pork, or tempeh. Mix with cauliflower rice for a BBQ 'fried rice'. Combine with Greek yogurt for a tangy, protein-rich sauce with less sugar per serving.
nutritionContext.timingConsiderations: Best used occasionally rather than daily. When consumed, pair with high-protein, high-fiber foods to minimize blood sugar impact. Avoid before bed due to sugar content affecting sleep quality.
